Award.AwardTitle: SL - CN: A Research-Practice Collaboration to Improve Math Learning in Young Children

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Science of Learning Collaborative Network brings together a diverse group of experts to examine how math knowledge and attitudes together affect early math achievement, and to develop tools to promote math learning at home and in school for children in kindergarten to grade three. The network focuses on early math because achievement in this domain is a powerful predictor of future academic success. Moreover, math is a cornerstone for careers in the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) and our technological society has a high need for a STEM workforce that can push the frontiers of innovation. Success in mathematics requires learning content, but also has social and emotional dimensions. Yet math instruction does not typically address the emotional dimension, instead focusing exclusively on content. This is particularly problematic because many parents and elementary school teachers have both high levels of math anxiety and less-than-optimal knowledge of how to promote math learning and interest in young children. The end result is a cycle of inter-generational transmission of low math achievement and high math anxiety.

To break this cycle, the network brings together: (a) researchers who study the knowledge and attitudes that support math achievement; (b) developers who translate research findings into effective educational tools; (c) practitioners who implement educational tools in real-world learning settings, and (d) experts in the dissemination of such tools. By combining these different kinds of expertise, the network will increase understanding of how young children learn math and develop attitudes about math. Further, the network will use this knowledge to support children's math learning at home and in school by developing a toolkit for parents and teachers to help them more effectively provide math instruction to children from diverse socioeconomic backgrounds. The network will evaluate whether the toolkit improves children's math learning and math attitudes as well as teachers' and parents' math attitudes, and will refine the toolkit based on feedback from those who are using it. Finally, the network will widely share the toolkit via a publicly available website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of SL-CN: A Research-Practice Collaboration to Improve Math Learning in Young Children were to advance our understanding of children?s math learning in the home environment and to share this understanding with families and family facing professionals. Our focus on early math was fueled by findings showing that children?s math knowledge at kindergarten entry is linked to their long-term math achievement, as well as findings showing that children?s early math learning opportunities, including learning opportunities with family members at home, are linked to their math knowledge at kindergarten entry. In order to accomplish these goals, we established a collaborative network consisting of a multidisciplinary team that included researchers in psychology and education, curriculum developers, professionals working with families and early childhood educators, and families themselves.

Our studies uncovered several specific practices that enhance early math learning during parent-child interactions.  First, when parents ask their children questions about number rather than just providing that information to them, parent-child math conversations are richer and provide more opportunities to learn.  Second, when parents read evidence-based number books with their children, children?s understanding of the meaning of number words increases (for example that ?two? corresponds to two objects).  Third, when children are just starting to understand the meanings of number words, children gain more when number books align with children?s skills and focus on small numbers, from 1 to 3, rather than focusing on a broader range of numbers as is typical in commercial counting books. Finally, children?s numerical skills increase more when numerical information and practice counting and labeling sets is embedded in meaningful stories, where there is a purpose to counting beyond practice. We also found that parent math anxiety and confidence about their own math abilities were related to how much they valued math achievement for their child as well as to their expectations that their child would do well in math in the future. Surprisingly, children?s early math skills did not relate to parents? expectations and value of math for their child. All of these findings have informed the development of the Becoming a Math Family website and app (see below) and will continue to inform future early math interventions for families of young children.

In terms of broader impact, our project resulted in the creation of the Becoming a Math Family website and app for families with 3- to 7-year-old children. These resources share evidence-based findings about young children?s math learning with parents and caregivers, including activities that support math learning and tips about how to support children?s math learning and positive math attitudes. In addition to grounding the website in the science of learning, the website was informed by the strengths, needs, and experiences of families. Further, in order to reach a broad audience, the website/app resources are available in English and Spanish. In a survey study carried out with parents whose children attended Head Start preschools, we found that compared to parents who did not use the website, parents who used the website had a stronger belief that math learning depends on effort and instruction rather than on a fixed ability. Usage data showed that traffic to the website increased dramatically during the Covid-19 crisis as many children were spending more time at home, reflecting an increased need for such resources. We are currently incorporating the website into a preschool based math intervention, and hypothesize that this school-home partnership will increase children?s math learning during the preschool years and result in stronger math achievement during formal schooling.
